subsections.title: TO + base verb (V1)
examples: I started going to bed at 10 to get more sleep.
I bought these chimes to hang on my window.
He stepped outside to smoke.
subsections.explanation: Use to + verb 1 for purpose. Never: *to getting*, *to relax-ing* when explaining reason.

subsections.title: FOR + noun
examples: I started going to bed at 10 for my health.
I bought these chimes for decoration.
He stepped outside for a cigarette.
subsections.explanation: Use for + noun when the reason is a thing, not an action.

subsections.title: FOR + -ing
examples: This app is for learning vocabulary.
Get off the chair. It's for sitting, not standing.
That tool? It's for making melon balls.
subsections.explanation: Use for + ing when explaining the specific function of an object.

subsections.title: TO = direction or movement
examples: I'm going to the park.
I gave the gift to Liz.
Did you speak to Paula?
I brought cookies to the picnic.
subsections.explanation: Use to when something moves toward a destination.
subsections.specialNote: I threw the ball to Lila. (so she can catch it) vs. I threw the ball at Lila. (she is the target)

subsections.title: TO ME = opinion
examples: It looks good to me.
To me, she seemed nervous.
subsections.explanation: Use to me when expressing personal opinion or perception.

subsections.title: FOR ME = effect / benefit / situation
examples: Exercise is good for me.
Meditating would be therapeutic for me.
That test was hard for me.
It's too expensive for me.
subsections.explanation: Use for me when something has an effect, benefit, or describes your situation.

subsections.title: FOR = being nice or doing something instead of someone
examples: I bought these flowers for you. (nice gesture)
A student baked cupcakes for the whole class.
My colleague was sick, so I taught her class for her. (instead of her)
Can you call the bank for me? (do it instead of me)
subsections.explanation: Use for when you help someone or act on their behalf.

subsections.title: When to is a preposition
structure: to + -ing (when to is part of phrasal verb/preposition)
examples: I'm looking forward to the show.
I'm looking forward to it.
I'm looking forward to going.
subsections.explanation: If to is part of a phrasal verb or preposition, it can take -ing.

summary.example: I go to the gym to exercise.
Can you do this for me?
